MOE Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Synthesis and Functionalization Department of Polymer Science and Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310058 China Graphical abstract The thermal stability of α-diimine nickel catalysts has always been a hot research topic, and its thermal deactivation mechanism has not been determined for the time being. In this work, three model α-diimine nickel catalysts with simple backbone structures and only one or two –CH3 differences were synthesized to catalyze ethylene polymerization at different temperatures. For the first time, the focus of catalyst thermal stability was related to the internal essence (active centers) from the external manifestation (thermal stability of catalyst structure, catalytic activity), and the quenching method of thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride (TPCC) was adopted to further elucidate the essence of catalyst thermal stability from the perspectives of the quantity (quantity of active centers at low/high temperature) and quality (insertion rate constant) of active centers. In this study, it is proposed that the thermal stability of catalysts is a result of the combined effect of the quantity and quality of active centers, while increasing the steric effect by means of increasing –CH3, etc., essentially affects the balance between the quantity and the quality of active centers. Designing suitable steric effects and finding the optimum point between the above influencing factors is one of the effective ways to improve the thermal stability of catalysts. Keywords α-Diimine nickel catalyst Thermal stability Active centers Ethylene polymerization Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Materials are the material basis of social development and have a milestone significance for the progress of human civilization. Polyolefin is the largest and most widely used polymer material in the world, with a total annual global output of more than 216 million tons, and has been on a growing trend in the past decade[1–6]. The global annual production of polyethylene, the most widely used polyolefin material, has long exceeded 117.8 million tons per year[4,7,8]. This is mainly due to the continuous development of coordination insertion polymerization[8–14]. Among these, late-transition metal catalysts have their own unique advantages such as lower oxygenophilicity, stronger polar group tolerance, and modulation to obtain nonlinear topologies[13–17]. Especially Brookhart et al[11,18] pioneered the application of α-diimine nickel/palladium complexes to the synthesis of polyolefins, after which late-transition metal catalysts began to receive widespread attention. However, the low catalytic activity or even inactivation of such complexes at high temperatures has imposed great limitations on their industrial applications[19]. Recently, researchers have made great progress in increasing the polymerization reaction temperature through their efforts[8,20–28]. However, the thermal deactivation mechanism of α-diimine nickel catalysts has not been clarified so far. Therefore, it is an important research direction to find the influencing factors of the thermal stability of α-diimine nickel catalysts and figure out the mechanism of high-temperature deactivation. In recent decades, the exploration of the thermal stability mechanism of such complexes has mainly focused on the perspectives of catalyst structure (e.g., N-aryl rotation[19,29–31], five-membered coordination ring stability[32,33], electronic effect[34–40], etc.) and catalytic system (e.g., co-catalyst[41–43], etc.). Taking these as different theoretical bases, researchers have used the addition of large site-resistant groups to the catalyst backbone structure[44–48] or N-aryl ortho-position[20,21,49–59] as well as the tuning of different electronic effector groups[34–40] to improve the thermal stability of such complexes. As a matter of fact, all of the above studies were judged comparatively by examining the structure and polymerization activity of the catalysts. However, the polymerization activity is only an apparent presentation, and its essence is the nature of the active center. Therefore, to gain insight into the nature of the differences in thermal stability, it is necessary to search for answers around the nature of the active center. The acyl chloride quenching method established by our group has become more mature after several generations of research and development, and has been successfully used in the microkinetic studies of Ziegler-Natta catalytic system[60–66], MAO metal catalytic system[67,68], and α-diimine nickel catalytic system[33,69]. At the end of the polymerization reaction, the polymerization reaction was quenched with thiophene-2-chloride (TPCC), and the acyl group in TPCC could react with the Ni-C bond of the metal Ni on the active center, tagging the acyl group with sulfur-containing groups at the end of the polymer chain. Since each polymer chain corresponds to an active center, the quantity of active centers in the polymerization reaction can be calculated by measuring the sulfur content in the product after the quenching reaction (Fig. 1 ). In this work, we attempt to use a relatively simplified model catalyst to explore the possible reasons affecting thermal stability from two perspectives: the catalyst structure and the quantity and quality of their active centers, to analyze the effect of the quantity and quality of the active centers on the catalytic activity, and to propose some perspectives for judging the thermal stability of catalysts. 2 Results and discussions 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of ligands and catalysts Synthesis of ligands L1 [70], L2 [46] and L3 [71] were carried out with reference to the literature (Fig. 2 ). All ligands were characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, mass spectrometry and elemental analysis. The characterization results were confirmed to be the target product by comparison with L1 [70,72–74], L2 [46,75,76] and L3 [77,78] reported in the literature, respectively. The catalyst structures and catalytic properties of Ni1 [18,79–84] and Ni3 [18,45,79,82,84–86] have been extensively studied in the literatures, while Ni2 has not been reported in the literature. Meanwhile, the study of the active centers of the above three catalysts has not been reported. Ni1, Ni2 and Ni3 were prepared in essentially the same way (Fig. 2) with yields of 86.1 %, 93.7 % and 92.2 %, respectively. Single crystals of Ni1 ( Figure S10 , Table S1 ), Ni2 (Fig. 3 , Table S2 ) and Ni3 ( Figure S12 , Table S3 ) were obtained by gas-phase diffusion using dichloromethane as a good solvent and anhydrous ether or n-heptane as a bad solvent, and analyzed by X-ray diffraction. The above Ni(II) complexes were all characterized by elemental analysis and IR spectrum. 2.2 Atmospheric pressure polymerization of ethylene Three α-diimine nickel model catalysts Ni1, Ni2 and Ni3 with simple structures differing only by one or two –CH3 were used to catalyze the polymerization of ethylene at different temperatures (Table 1 ). It is obvious that the trends of the catalytic activities of the three catalysts catalyzing ethylene polymerization vary greatly with the increase of polymerization temperature under the same other polymerization conditions. At a lower polymerization temperature (20 °C), the catalytic activity of Ni1 for ethylene polymerization was slightly higher than that of Ni2 and much higher than that of Ni3. With the increase of polymerization temperature, the catalytic activity of Ni1 plummeted, which was lower than that of Ni2 and Ni3 at 40 °C, and was basically inactivated at 60 °C. The catalytic activity of Ni2 maintained high stability at lower temperatures (20–40 °C), and did not plummet until the temperature was increased to 60–80 °C. The highest activity of Ni3 was lower than that of Ni1 and Ni2, but in the process of polymerization temperature increase, the activity always remained relatively stable, in a small range of first increase and then decrease. Ni3 remained active at higher temperatures (80 °C) and was largely inactivated until 100 °C. From the above experimental phenomena, it can be preliminarily judged that Ni1 has the highest sensitivity to temperature, and almost loses its activity when the polymerization temperature is slightly increased; Ni2 has a certain degree of tolerance to the temperature until it loses its activity at higher temperatures; Ni3 has the lowest sensitivity to the temperature, and the catalytic activity can be kept relatively stable from low to high temperatures. Although the structures of these three catalysts differ by only one or two –CH3, the sensitivity to temperature varies enormously. The reasons for the differences in thermal stability can be analyzed in terms of catalyst structures and active centers, respectively. 2.3 Thermal stability of catalyst structures The thermal stability of the catalyst structure itself is one of the key factors affecting the stability of the active center. To further explore the reasons for the differences in the thermal stability of the catalysts due to the subtle changes in the backbone structure, the single-crystal structures of these three catalysts were comparatively analyzed. The thermal decomposition process of the catalysts was analyzed by TGA experiments, and the possible dissociation modes of the catalysts were calculated. Observation of the single-crystal structures of Ni1, Ni2, and Ni3 reveals that the steric structures of the three catalysts have been altered considerably, although the difference in composition is small. This change is mainly reflected in the conformational difference of the five-membered ring where Ni and N are located. In our preliminary work[33], it was found that the conformation of the five-membered coordination ring in which the metal active center is located may have a large impact on the stability of the catalysts. In terms of bond lengths and bond angles, the five-membered rings of Ni1 and Ni3 are axisymmetric, while Ni2 is asymmetric(Fig. 4 ). From the two-sided angle, Ni1 can be approximated by viewing the five-membered coordination ring as a plane; Ni3 metal center Ni is located outside the plane formed by N1-C1-C2-N2, and the five-membered coordination ring forms the classical envelope conformation; the conformation of Ni2 is not one of the three common conformations of the five-membered ring (planar, half-chair, and envelope), and the five-membered ring of Ni2 exhibits a more distorted attitude, similar to that of the butterfly conformation of cyclobutane (Fig. 4). Therefore, it can be concluded that five-membered ring whose exist as an approximate planar conformation is the least stable among these three catalysts, five-membered ring whose exist as a standard envelope conformation is the most stable, and whose is similar to the butterfly conformation is intermediate in stability, i.e., from the five-membered ring stability, the order of thermal stability of the catalyst is Ni3 > Ni2 > Ni1. The TGA test allows for a more visual observation of the thermal stability of the three catalysts (Fig. 5 ). From the TGA curves of the three catalysts, it can be seen that a mass reduction starts to occur after 200 °C, followed by a rapid mass reduction. Since the catalysts are complexes of NiBr2 and ligand, the increase in temperature is most likely to break the complex. The percentage of sample mass remaining at the inflection point when the rate of mass reduction slows down for the three samples is around 34 % within the measurement error, which is in general agreement with the theoretical content of NiBr2 in the catalyst (around 35 %). Thus the temperature increases and the ligand is dislodged and thermally decomposed, leading to mass reduction. Comparing the decomposition temperatures of the three catalysts (using 95 % mass residue as the onset of the thermal decomposition temperature), Ni3 (249 °C) > Ni2 (228 °C) > Ni1 (211 °C), which further confirms the thermal stability of the three catalyst structures Ni3 > Ni2 > Ni1. In fact, from the experimental results, the catalyst decomposes at high temperatures higher than the deactivation temperature of the active center during polymerization (generally not higher than 200 °C). Therefore, the TGA analysis only proves that the structure of the catalyst itself does not thermally decompose at the polymerization temperature. To further analyze the thermal stability of the catalyst structure, we calculated the dissociation energy of the structure associated with the catalyst metal center. The Gaussian 16 program was used, and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) density generalization method was used in the calculations, with the C, N, H and Ni atoms having a basis set of 6-311G(d, p), and the Br atoms having a basis set of LanL2Dz. The results are shown in Table 2 . There are several possibilities for the structural decomposition of the α-diimine nickel catalyst: (R1) N-Ni breaks off and NiBr2 falls off the catalyst; (R2-1) Ni-Br breaks off first, and (R2-2) N-Ni then breaks off; and (R3) Ni-Br and N-Ni break off at the same time. Calculations revealed that R1 requires the lowest energy and therefore this type of decomposition is most likely to occur. Comparing the R1 decomposition energies of the three catalysts, Ni3 > Ni2 > Ni1, that is, with the increase of polymerization temperature, Ni1 is the most unstable and easiest to decompose, Ni3 is the most stable and not easy to decompose, and Ni2 is in the middle of the stability. This is consistent with the results obtained from the TGA test. 2.4 Thermal stability of active centers It is well known that catalysts need to be activated by co-catalysts to form active centers with the ability to catalyze ethylene polymerization. The co-catalyst attacks the metal center and forms a coordination bond with the metal center and a vacancy that allows ethylene to be coordinated, thus forming the active center. Therefore, thermal stability of active centers (quantity and quality) is the key factor affecting the catalytic activity. 2.4.1 The quantity of active centers It is crucial to find a method to study the quantity of active centers directly and objectively. The thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride (TPCC) quenching method was used to study the changes in the quantity of active centers during the catalytic polymerization of ethylene at different polymerization temperatures, so that the effects of the changes in the backbone structure on the thermal stability of the active centers could be further explored (Table 3 ). (1) Quantity of active centers at low temperature At a lower polymerization temperature (20 °C), the quantity of active centers of these three catalytic systems was Ni1 > Ni3 > Ni2(Table 3). This may be related to the ease with which the catalysts can form active centers (steric effect and electronic effect). The steric structure of the catalyst, especially the spatial environment around the metal center, affects the attack of the co-catalyst to a large extent, which in turn affects the difficulty of forming the active center of the catalyst. Using the SambVca2.1 program[87] to calculate the buried volume (topographic steric maps) of Ni1, Ni2 and Ni3, the influence of the steric effect of the ligand on the ability to form active centers can be visually analyzed, and the smaller the buried volume is, the higher the probability of the co-catalyst attacking the metal centers is, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . The buried volume around the metal center Ni of Ni1 (79.7 %) is the smallest, Ni3 (81.4 %) is the second largest, and Ni2 (82.5 %) is the largest. From the calculations, we know that it is not the case that the more –CH3 there is, the larger the buried volume is. In fact, the relative position of –CH3 to the metal center Ni is the key factor affecting the buried volume. The catalyst structures of Ni1 and Ni3 are symmetric, and thus the buried volumes of the four spatial orientations of the metal center Ni are also symmetric; whereas, the asymmetry of the catalyst structure of Ni2 results in an exceptionally large buried volume (90.0 %) in the South-East orientation, which increases the difficulty of the co-catalysts in attacking the metal center. That is to say, these three catalysts are analyzed from the perspective of the steric effect around the metal center, and the ability of the co-catalysts to attack the metal center Ni to form an active center is in the order of Ni1 > Ni3 > Ni2 from easy to difficult. From the electronic effects, changes in the backbone structure also have an impact on the distribution of the electron cloud in the metal centers, thus affecting the ability of the catalyst to form active centers. The natural bond orbital (NBO) analyses were calculated for natural atomic charge using the Gaussian 16 program (Fig. 7 , Table S4 ). The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) density generalization method was used in the calculations, with the C, N, H and Ni atoms having a basis set of 6-311G(d, p), and the Br atoms having a basis set of LanL2Dz. Analysis of the data reveals that in the pristine state of the catalyst before activation by the co-catalyst, the differences in the NBO charges of the metal centers Ni are very small, 1.136 (Ni1), 1.118 (Ni2), and 1.128 (Ni3), respectively. This may be due to the fact that the two Br atoms attached to Ni are strong electron pulling groups, which weakens the electron donating effect of the –CH3 group. On the other hand, Br atoms are directly connected to the metal center Ni, whereas –CH3 is located on the backbone structure farther away from the metal center. Therefore, the effect of –CH3 on the metal center is much weaker. But even so, the NBO charges of metal center Ni on the three catalysts are slightly different. –CH3 is an electron-donating group, and an increase in –CH3 on the skeleton structure would theoretically increase the electron cloud density on metal center Ni. Nevertheless, the calculated NBO charges do not correspond to this theoretical result. Ni2 does have a smaller NBO charge than Ni1 due to the increase in –CH3, i.e., the electron cloud density becomes larger, which is consistent with the theoretical results; however, Ni3 has one more –CH3 than Ni2 but a larger NBO charge value. This may need to be analyzed in relation to the catalyst structure. The five-membered ring (N = C–C = N and Ni) of Ni1 is approximately in the same plane, N = C–C = N has the conjugation effect, and the electrons undergo delocalization to form a large π-bond; for Ni2, due to the structural asymmetry of the five-membered ring, N = C–C = N does not lie in the same plane, and the conjugation effect is disrupted. The electron-donating effect of –CH3 on the backbone is smoothly transferred to the metal center Ni, and the density of the electron cloud is increased. The N = C–C = N in Ni3 is also in the same plane with conjugation effect to form a large π-bond, and the angle between –CH3 on the backbone and this plane is only 4.87°, then the large π-bond between –CH3 and N = C–C = N may form a hyperconjugation effect of σ-π conjugation, and the electrons undergo delocalization in this region. Whereas the N-Ni-N plane has an angle of 14.30° with this plane, the electrons may be confined to the delocalized region, and thus the electron cloud density of Ni is smaller than that of Ni2. Since the larger the NBO charge of the metal center Ni, the easier it is for the co-catalyst to attack the metal center, thus forming the active centers in the order of Ni1 > Ni3 > Ni2 from easiest to hardest. The Gibbs free energy (ΔG) for the alkylation of catalyst LNiBr2 alkane by a co-catalyst (AlEt2Cl) to form [LNiEt]+ is a more intuitive response to the difference in catalyst activation capacity (Equation (1) . DFT calculations of the ΔG (kcal/mol) for the alkylation process for the three different catalysts were − 12.57 (Ni1), −10.16 (Ni2), and − 10.72 (Ni3), respectively. Among them, Ni1 has the lowest ΔG and is the easiest to be alkylated to form active centers, while Ni2 has the highest ΔG and is the hardest to be alkylated. Therefore, from the point of view of the ΔG of alkylation, the ability of the catalyst to form active centers is Ni1 > Ni3 > Ni2 from easy to difficult. (1) LNiB r 2 + 2 A l E t 2 C l → LNiEt + · AlE t 3 C l - + A l B r 2 C l That is to say, under the same lower polymerization temperature and other same polymerization conditions, try to exclude other factors that cause catalyst decomposition and deactivation, the ability to form active centers is in the order of Ni1 > Ni3 > Ni2. This also explains the ordering of the quantity of active centers of the three catalysts at lower temperatures as Ni1 > Ni3 > Ni2 (Table 3). For the three catalysts in this paper, the addition of –CH3 reduces the quantity of active centers. It seems contrary to popular belief. In fact, the more critical factor affecting the formation of active centers in catalysts is the difference in steric effect caused by the relative position of –CH3 in the catalyst structure, not just the amount of –CH3. This steric effect not only changes the size of the space around the metal center Ni, but also affects the electronic effect of the metal center Ni. (2) Quantity of active centers at high temperature With the increase of polymerization temperature, the quantity of active centers in Ni1 tended to decrease, while these in Ni2 and Ni3 first increased and then decreased (Table 3). At the comparable higher temperature (60 °C), the active centers in the Ni1 catalytic system are basically inactivated, while the active centers in the Ni2 (5.8 mol-%) and Ni3 (19.9 mol-%) catalytic system are still active. Even if the temperature is raised to 80 °C, the active centers in the Ni3 are still 12.5 mol-% of the total Ni atoms (Table 3). That is to say, under the same higher polymerization temperature and other same polymerization conditions, the quantity of active centers is in the order of Ni3 > Ni2 > Ni1. This is because when the polymerization temperature is increased, the catalysts all alkylate more readily to form active centers, and the difference in the ease of alkylation becomes smaller. Coordination and insertion of ethylene as well as competition between chain growth, chain walking and chain transfer become the main source of differences. The biggest difference between the steric structure of the freshly formed active centers and that of the catalysts is that both Br attached to the metal center Ni are replaced by the alkylation process of the co-catalysts with an alkyl group and a vacancy, so the calculation of the embedded volume after removing the two Br allows an approximate comparison of the effect of the steric effect on the ethylene coordination after their alkylation to become the active centers (Fig. 8 ). The ethylene molecules coordinated to the active center vacancies during chain growth are relatively small, whereas the main body undergoing chain transfer and chain walking is the relatively bulky polyethylene chain. Both chain walking and chain transfer occur as β-H elimination reactions, but the difference is that the polyethylene chain is flipped and reinserted after the β-H elimination reaction in chain walking, whereas it falls off the metal center Ni after the β-H elimination reaction in chain transfer. When the steric effect of the active center of the catalyst increases, the ground state energy of the dormant state increases, the energy barrier for the insertion of the ethylene monomer decreases [88,89], the ethylene monomer is more likely to continue to be inserted, and chain walking is more dominant than chain transfer. Thus the steric effect around the metal center Ni plays a very important role in regulating the competition between chain walking and chain transfer reactions. When the steric effect around the metal center Ni is relatively small, the polyethylene chains are more likely to fall off from the metal center and chain transfer is more dominant over chain walking. Therefore, although Ni1 is more likely to form an active center, the polyethylene chain is also most likely to fall off from the metal center, and the number of its active centers can reach a high state at the early stage of polymerization, and the increase in the quantity of active centers is not obvious with the increase in polymerization time; when the steric effect around the metal center Ni becomes larger, the polyethylene chains are more inclined to rotate after β-H elimination before reinsertion, i.e., they are more inclined to undergo chain walking, at which time the molecular weight of the polyethylene increases along with the degree of branching. With the increase of polymerization time, the numbers of active centers of Ni2 and Ni3 increase significantly compared to that of Ni1 at higher polymerization temperature. Ni3 is the least likely to form active centers in the early stage of the polymerization reaction, and thus the quantity of active centers is relatively small compared to that of Ni1 and Ni2. With the increase of polymerization time, the active centers formed by Ni3 are least prone to chain transfer due to the maximum site resistance around the metal center Ni, while Ni3 has the lowest energy barrier for vinyl insertion relative to Ni1 and Ni2, and the insertion of vinyl monomers is the decisive step for chain growth [90], with the largest increase in the quantity of active centers. After the catalyst alkylation, the active centers are formed, and the metal center Ni are also affected by the electronic effect brought by the change of the backbone structure. By replacing the two Br on the metal center Ni with an alkyl group and a vacancy and calculating the NBO charge of the metal center Ni in this state, the influence of the electronic effect can be roughly compared (Fig. 9 , Table S5 ). The smaller the NBO charges of metal center Ni, the higher the electron cloud density. When atomic orbitals overlap to form molecular orbitals, if the density of atomic orbital overlap is higher (i.e., the higher the electron cloud density), the probability of electrons appearing between the two nuclei becomes larger, which may lead to smaller nuclear spacing and lower total potential energy, resulting in a more stable molecule. Therefore, the higher the electron cloud density of the metal center, the more stable the active center with polymer chains attached. The order of stability of the active centers formed by the above three catalysts is Ni3 > Ni2 > Ni1, analyzed from the point of view of electronic effects. Therefore, when the polymerization temperature is high, from the quantity of active centers at 30 min of polymerization time, Ni1, although generating more active centers, is also the most prone to chain transfer, with the least quantity of active centers in real time. Ni3, although the least prone to forming active centers, accumulates the most active centers due to the relative lack of chain transfer. The difference in steric effect between Ni2 and Ni3 is not significant (Fig. 8), and thus the quantity of active centers does not differ much relative to Ni1 over a range of temperatures (Table 3). However, the quantity of active centers decreases rapidly after the polymerization temperature is increased to the point where the transfer of the active center chain formed by Ni2 becomes the dominant reaction. At this point, the small difference in steric effect and electronic effect of Ni3 continues to be dominant (chain walking is more dominant than chain transfer) and the quantity of active centers is maintained at a high level. The quantity of active centers formed by Ni3 eventually decreases rapidly as the polymerization temperature continues to increase due to chain transfer becoming the dominant reaction. 2.4.2 The quality of active centers The monomer insertion rate constant is a more intuitive response to the quality of the active center. The rate constant of monomer insertion, k pi, can be calculated by Equation (2) [91–93]: (2) R pi = k pi C ∗ M i where R pi is the insertion rate of monomer i at t p, k pi is the insertion rate constant for monomer i (in this work i = ethylene, abbreviated as E), [Mi] is the concentration of monomer i at t p, and [C*] is the concentration of the active center at t p. The [Mi] used in the calculations is the equilibrium concentration of ethylene in the system, the value of which was calculated from the literature[94]. R pi can be calculated from the monomer consumed (i.e., the yield of polyethylene) and the polymerization time (Table 3). It can be found that the insertion rate constants k pE of the active centers formed by these three catalysts increased to different degrees with the increase of polymerization temperature. k pE of the active centers of the Ni1 and Ni2 catalytic systems increased insignificantly, while k pE of the active centers of the Ni3 catalytic system, although much smaller than those of Ni1 and Ni2 at low temperatures, increased rapidly with the increase of polymerization temperature. At higher polymerization temperatures, the k pE of the active centers of these three catalytic systems were in the order of Ni3 > Ni2 > Ni1. Combined with the quantity of active centers, when the polymerization temperature was a lower 20 °C, the quantity of active centers of Ni1 (27.3 mol-%) was higher than that of Ni2 (19.1 mol-%), and at this time, the insertion rate constants of Ni1 and Ni2 were similar, so the catalytic activity of Ni1 was higher than that of Ni2.The quantity of active centers of Ni2 and Ni3 were similar (about 20 mol-%), but the insertion rate constant of Ni3 (75 L/mol·s) were much lower than those of Ni2 (270 L/mol·s), and thus the catalytic activity of Ni2 was higher than that of Ni3. With the increase of polymerization temperature, the quantity of active centers of Ni1 decreased rapidly, while Ni2 and Ni3 slightly increased and then decreased to different degrees. At this time, the insertion rate constants of Ni1 and Ni2 did not grow significantly, so the catalytic activity continued to decline; while the insertion rate constant of Ni3 became larger rapidly with the increase of polymerization temperature, and the quantity of active centers decreased slowly. Therefore, the catalytic activity of Ni3 showed a trend of increasing and then decreasing. In summary, the catalytic activity is the result of the joint action of the quantity and quality of active centers. 2.5 Several perspectives for determining the thermal stability of catalysts Three α-diimine nickel model catalysts Ni1, Ni2 and Ni3 were used to catalyze the pressurized polymerization of ethylene at different temperatures (Table 4 ). From Fig. 10 , it is obvious that the trends of the catalytic activities of the three catalysts catalyzing ethylene polymerization vary greatly with the increase of polymerization temperature under the same other polymerization conditions. The polymerization activity of Ni1 catalyzed ethylene polymerization just reached 1.15 × 106 g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h at 40 °C, and the catalytic activity rapidly decreased by 2 orders of magnitude as the polymerization temperature increased to 60 °C. The catalytic activity of Ni2 and Ni3 can easily reach more than 5 × 106g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h at 40 °C. Differently, during the process of polymerization temperature rising to 100 °C, the catalytic activity of Ni2 showed an accelerated decreasing trend from 5.23 × 106g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h at lower polymerization temperature to 1.07 × 106g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h at 70 °C, and the catalytic activity had been reduced by 2 orders of magnitude even at 100 °C. While the catalytic activity of Ni3 showed a decelerating downward trend, Ni3 always maintained a high catalytic activity during the gradual increase of the polymerization temperature, and its catalytic activity could still reach 1.00 × 106g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h at the polymerization temperature up to 100 °C, and even when the polymerization temperature continued to rise to 120 °C, the catalytic activity was still able to maintain at 105g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h. (1) Maximum temperature of high catalytic activity If one of the more conventional polymerization conditions (autoclave: 300 mL; [Ni] = 10 μmol/L; cocatalysts: AlEt2Cl; Al:Ni = 600; solvent: heptane; pressure: 0.7 MPa; polymerization time, 30 min.) is used as the standard polymerization condition for comparing the thermal stability of these three catalysts, and the highest polymerization temperature at which the catalysts can catalyze the polymerization of ethylene with a catalytic activity of 106 g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h is taken as the ‘maximum temperature of high catalytic activity’, the ‘maximum temperature of high catalytic activity’ of Ni1, Ni2 and Ni3 is 40 °C, 70 °C and 100 °C, respectively. This is essentially the same as ‘comparing the catalyst activity under the same polymerization conditions’, which is the most basic, simple and commonly used intuitive criterion for judging the thermal stability of catalysts. From this point of view, although there is only a small change in the catalyst backbone structure from two −H, one –CH3 to two –CH3, there is a huge difference in catalytic activity at the same polymerization temperature. The difference in the ‘maximum temperature of high catalytic activity’ can even reach about 30 °C. According to this criterion, Ni3 is the best thermally stable catalyst, Ni2 is the second best, and Ni1 is the worst, i.e. Ni3 > Ni2 > Ni1. (2) Catalytic activity decay In terms of the response of catalytic activity to polymerization temperature, the thermal stability of these three catalysts with minor structural differences also showed three distinct trends, namely, the low activity decline of Ni1, the accelerated decline of high activity of Ni2 and the decelerated decline of high activity of Ni3, respectively. The catalytic activity trends of Ni1 and Ni2 with increasing temperature were relatively similar, and both of them had accelerated declines. The difference was that the catalytic activity of Ni1 was relatively low, while the catalytic activity of Ni2 was higher at lower temperature, so the catalytic activity had a larger decline with the increase of polymerization temperature. However, the decreasing trend was very different from that of the two previous catalysts, as Ni3 had no obvious decreasing trend until 70 °C, and the catalytic activity was maintained at a high level until the polymerization temperature was increased to above 80 °C, and then it began to decrease rapidly. The decay of catalytic activity with the increase of polymerization temperature is also one of the important indexes to investigate the thermal stability of catalysts. In this paper, in order to compare the above indexes of these three catalysts, the activity decrease ratio at 100 °C and 40 °C was taken as the decay rate. Then, the average value of catalytic activity of catalysts at different temperatures and the catalytic activity of catalysts at the median temperature were calculated and compared. The above three indicators were used as the decay to evaluate the thermal stability of the catalysts. The decay rate of Ni1 already reached 96.5 % at 60 °C, and both the average catalytic activity and the catalytic activity at the median temperature were only at the level of 105g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h, which was not only relatively low but also a significant decay of the activity. Ni2 and Ni3 can be compared in the same polymerization temperature range (40 ∼ 100 °C). In terms of the decay rate, the decay rate of Ni2 was 99.2 % at the same polymerization temperature of 100 °C, whereas the decay rate of Ni3 was only 81.9 %, and there was still about 20 % of space for the activity to continue to be decayed at the same polymerization temperature, and even at the polymerization temperature of 120 °C, the decay rate of Ni3 was only 96.4 %, which was still smaller than that of Ni1 at the polymerization temperature of 60 °C and that of Ni2 at the polymerization temperature of 100 °C. In terms of average catalytic activity, the average catalytic activity of Ni2 was 2.1 × 106g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h, and the average catalytic activity of Ni3 was nearly twice that of Ni2, reaching 3.9 × 106g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h. From the point of view of the catalytic activity at the neutralization temperature of 70 °C, the catalytic activity of Ni3 was even four times that of Ni2. From the above three indicators to judge the thermal stability of these three catalysts with only minor structural changes in terms of decay, Ni3 has the smallest decay amplitude, the slowest decay rate, and the best thermal stability, followed by Ni2, and Ni1 is the worst, i.e., Ni3 > Ni2 > Ni1. (3) High catalytic activity persistence The ability of a catalyst to continue to catalyze ethylene polymerization with high activity at higher polymerization temperatures is also one of the most important indicators of a catalyst's thermal stability and is generally referred to as the catalyst's ‘lifetime’. The previous work generally focused on the duration of catalytic activity of different catalysts at the same polymerization temperature, which was a relatively direct comparison of this indicator. However, the problem is that different catalysts have different ‘maximum temperature of high catalytic activity’, and some catalysts are not even active at higher temperatures, so it is impossible to find a relatively fixed comparison temperature. In order to solve this problem, the ‘maximum temperature of high catalytic activity’ of each catalyst can be used as the polymerization temperature to examine the continuity of high activity of the catalyst. In other words, at the maximum temperature each catalyst can reach an activity of 106g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h, the duration for which the catalyst maintains a higher activity (decreasing to about 1/3 of the original activity, i.e., 3 × 105g(PE)/mol(Ni)·h) is examined, and is called as ‘high catalytic activity persistence’. The catalytic activities of ethylene polymerization catalyzed by Ni1, Ni2 and Ni3 at different polymerization time were investigated at their corresponding ‘maximum temperature of high catalytic activity’, and the results are listed in Table 5 . The results show that the catalytic activity of Ni1 at its ‘high activity thermal stability maximum temperature’ decreased to about 1/4 at the polymerization time of 60 min, and thus the ‘high catalytic activity persistence’ of Ni1 was less than 60 min, while the ‘high catalytic activity persistence’ of Ni2 and Ni3 at their respective ‘maximum temperature of high catalytic activity’ decreased to 1/3 at the polymerization time of 120 min. Indeed, the activity of three catalysts at 120 min is half of that at 60 min, indicating that three catalysts are nearly inactive after 60 min. Three catalysts show poor thermal stability at highest activity temperatures. On the basis of this experimental result, it is possible to compare the thermal stability between the three catalysts in terms of the duration of activity reduction to a uniform standard and the magnitude of the ‘maximum temperature of high catalytic activity’. Therefore, the thermal stability of the catalysts at higher temperatures in terms of the persistence of high activity is comparable between Ni2 and Ni3, while Ni1 is worse, i.e., Ni3≈Ni2 > Ni1. In summary, an all-round examination of the thermal stability of catalysts can be analyzed from the following three perspectives: maximum temperature of high catalytic activity, catalytic activity decay, and high catalytic activity persistence. These three perspectives represent, respectively, the highest polymerization temperature that the catalyst can tolerate to maintain high activity, the speed and degree of activity decrease of the catalyst during the process of increasing polymerization temperature, and the time that the catalyst can maintain high activity. Taking Ni1, Ni2 and Ni3, which have only minor differences in the backbone structure, as an example, Ni1 performed poorly in the above three aspects, while Ni2 only changed from one −H to one –CH3 in the backbone, and its performance in the above three aspects was essentially improved; Ni3 changed from two −H to two –CH3 in the backbone of Ni1, and its performance in the three aspects of the above thermal stability was even more excellent than that of Ni2. Especially, the catalyst showed excellent thermal stability in terms of ‘high catalytic activity’ and ‘catalytic activity decay’. 3 Conclusion In this work, three model catalysts Ni1, Ni2 and Ni3 with minimal structural differences were used to catalyze the polymerization of ethylene at different temperatures, and the effects of small changes in the catalyst structures on their catalytic polymerization behaviors and thermal stability were investigated. The accuracy of the results was confirmed by experiments and theoretical calculations in terms of the quantity of active centers (the quantity of active centers at low/high temperature) and the quality of the active centers (insertion rate constant). This study shows that increasing the amount of –CH3 is only superficial, and the most direct key is to affect the steric effect around the metal at the center of the catalyst structure (there may also be electronic effects). The steric effect coordinates the balance between active center formation (alkylation) and active center dormancy (chain transfer), which directly affects the quantity of active centers; at the same time, the steric effect affects the quality of active centers (insertion rate constant). Catalyst thermal stability is a result of the combined effect of the number and quality of active centers. Therefore, designing a suitable space site resistance and finding the optimum point for these competing influences are the key to improving the thermal stability of catalysts. The focus of catalyst thermal stability was firstly related to the internal essence (active centers) from the external manifestation (catalytic activity), and the quenching method of thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride was adopted to further elucidate the essence of catalyst thermal stability from the perspectives of the quantity and quality of active centers, which adds a new research idea to the exploration of the mechanism of thermal deactivation of catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The thermal stability of α-diimine nickel catalysts has always been a hot research topic, and its thermal deactivation mechanism has not been determined for the time being. In this work, three model α-diimine nickel catalysts with simple backbone structures and only one or two –CH3 differences were synthesized to catalyze ethylene polymerization at different temperatures. For the first time, the focus of catalyst thermal stability was related to the internal essence (active centers) from the external manifestation (thermal stability of catalyst structure, catalytic activity), and the quenching method of thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride (TPCC) was adopted to further elucidate the essence of catalyst thermal stability from the perspectives of the quantity (quantity of active centers at low/high temperature) and quality (insertion rate constant) of active centers. In this study, it is proposed that the thermal stability of catalysts is a result of the combined effect of the quantity and quality of active centers, while increasing the steric effect by means of increasing –CH3, etc., essentially affects the balance between the quantity and the quality of active centers. Designing suitable steric effects and finding the optimum point between the above influencing factors is one of the effective ways to improve the thermal stability of catalysts.
